title: West Boylston town administrator fired after Trump flag dispute sues town
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Former West Boylston town administrator James Ryan sues the town for $1.3 million, alleging wrongful termination.
Ryan was fired following a dispute with Police Chief Dennis Minnich over a Trump flag in a public building.
The lawsuit claims Ryan's termination was retaliation by the Select Board for enforcing ethics policies on political signs.

title: 18-year-old injured in R.I. after lighting himself on fire for TikTok challenge
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: An 18-year-old was hospitalized with severe burns in North Smithfield, R.I., after a TikTok challenge went wrong.
The incident occurred when he and a 16-year-old poured gasoline on themselves and jumped into Slatersville Reservoir.
No trespassing charges have been filed despite the challenge involving private property above the reservoir.

title: ‘Fear and uncertainty’: Everett officials cancel Hispanic Heritage Month festival amid ICE crackdown
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Everett officials canceled the Fiesta Del Rio, scheduled for Sept. 20, due to recent ICE raids in the area.
The annual Hispanic Heritage Month event was meant to showcase local Hispanic-owned businesses, music, and food in Rivergreen Park.
Mayor Carlo DeMaria stated the event's cancellation stems from community members' fear and uncertainty amid ICE crackdowns.

title: Josh Kraft ends mayoral campaign after coming in second by nearly 50 points in Tuesday’s preliminary
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Josh Kraft ends his mayoral campaign after losing to Mayor Michelle Wu by nearly 50 points in the preliminary election.
Kraft raised $6.8 million, including $5.5 million of his own money, but failed to advance in Boston's mayoral race.
Kraft plans to donate $3 million to address the humanitarian crisis near Massachusetts Avenue and Melnea Cass Boulevard.

title: Josh McDaniels defends Drake Maye: ‘He’s the right guy’ for Patriots
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Josh McDaniels defended quarterback Drake Maye amid criticism following the Patriots' Week 1 loss to the Raiders.
Maye completed 14 of 20 passes for 150 yards and a touchdown, but struggled after an interception.
McDaniels emphasized a long-term vision for Maye, citing expected learning curves and growing pains.

title: Authorities in a Connecticut town want to speak with whoever is painting the squirrels
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: East Hartford Animal Control reports two squirrels were painted red and blue near Naubuc Avenue and High Street.
The squirrels appear unharmed; authorities are consulting a wildlife rehabilitator for appropriate actions.
Public is urged to call 860-291-7572 with any information on the squirrel painting incident.

title: 2 Mass. teachers reportedly on leave for reactions to Charlie Kirk’s death
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Two Massachusetts teachers are on leave after controversial social media reactions to Charlie Kirk's death.
The Wachusett and Framingham superintendents confirmed the teachers' leaves and emphasized non-violence at their schools.
Charlie Kirk was shot in Utah while speaking about gun violence; police presence increased at involved schools.

title: A top return from Bruins’ roster teardown, prospect Fraser Minten is looking to stick in NHL
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Fraser Minten acquired by Bruins from Maple Leafs along with 2026 first-round draft pick.
Minten aims to secure a spot in Bruins' lineup after playing 25 NHL games.
Minten praised for maturity and versatility; participating in 2025 Prospects Challenge.

title: Police issue all clear after UMass Boston reports ‘public safety threat’
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: UMass Boston issued an all-clear after a reported 'public safety threat' on September 11, 2025.
The threat was linked to the Residence Hall East Building; no shots fired or firearms confirmed, police said.
Boston police and EMS responded to 240 Morrissey Blvd.; classes and evening activities were canceled.

title: ‘I would join a boycott’: Why readers oppose Market Basket’s firing of Artie T.
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Over 2,500 Boston.com readers, 86%, oppose the firing of Market Basket CEO Artie T. Demoulas.
Market Basket's board dismissed Demoulas due to alleged non-cooperation with financial and operational directives.
61% of readers surveyed plan to boycott Market Basket in response to Artie T.'s firing.
